content.text: The student ensures that the metre rule is horizontal
Briefly describe how to check that the rule is horizontal. You may draw a diagram if it helps to explain your answer

The student sets the distance \(d\) between the \(0.0 \text{cm}\) mark and the \(1.00 \text{N}\) load as shown in Fig. 1.1. He moves the thread supporting the \(1.00 \text{N}\) load so that it is at the mark on the metre rule shown in Fig. 1.2
Record the distance \(d\) indicated on Fig. 1.2
The readings on newton meter P and newton meter Q are shown in Fig. 1.3
Record \(F_{\mathrm{p}}\), the reading on newton meter P shown in Fig. 1.3
Record \(F_{\mathrm{Q}}\), the reading on newton meter Q shown in Fig. 1.3
\( F_{\mathrm{p}} \)  =
\( F_{\mathrm{Q}} \)  =
The student moves the \(1.00 \text{N}\) load to distances \(d = 25.0 \text{cm}, d = 35.0 \text{cm}, d = 45.0 \text{cm}, d = 55.0 \text{cm}\) and \(d = 65.0 \text{cm}\)
He reads the value \(F_{\mathrm{p}}\) on newton meter P and the value \(F_{\mathrm{Q}}\) on newton meter Q. His readings are shown in Table 1.1
Using the values from Table 1.1, plot a graph of \(F_{\mathrm{p}} / \mathrm{N}\) (y-axis) against \(d / \mathrm{cm}\) (x-axis)
On the same axes, and using the same scales, plot a graph of \(F_{\mathrm{Q}} / \mathrm{N}\) (y-axis) against \(d / \mathrm{cm}\) (x-axis)
Draw two best-fit lines, one for each set of plots. Show clearly on your graph which line is for \(F_{\mathrm{p}}\) and which line is for \(F_{\mathrm{Q}}\)
From your graph, determine \(F_{\mathrm{0}}\), the value of \(F_{\mathrm{p}}\) where the two best-fit lines cross
Calculate the weight \(W_{\mathrm{R}}\) of the metre rule, using the equation \(W_{\mathrm{R}} = (2 \times F_{\mathrm{0}}) - k\), where \(k = 1.00 \text{N}\)

Another student does the experiment with the same equipment. He reads values of \(F_{\mathrm{p}}\) which are the same as those in Table 1.1 but his values of \(F_{\mathrm{Q}}\) are all 0.10N greater than those in Table 1.1
Suggest a reason for this difference. Assume that the values in Table 1.1 are correct
A student investigates the forces supporting a metre rule
He uses the apparatus shown in Fig. 1.1. The scale of the metre rule faces upwards
Record the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) shown on the thermometer in Fig. 2.1
\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\)
Describe **one** precaution that can be taken to ensure that temperature readings in the experiment are as accurate as possible
The student pours a volume of \(150 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker and records the temperature \(\theta\) at time \(t = 0\)
She records the temperature of the water in the beaker every 30 s
She tips the water out and pours a volume of \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker. The student repeats the temperature measurements for this volume of water
Write a conclusion stating how the volume of water affects the rate of cooling of the water. Justify your answer by reference to the results
Using the results for \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of water, calculate the average cooling rate \(x\) for the first \(90 \text{s}\) of the experiment. Use the readings from Table 2.1 and the equation
where \(T = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_0\) and \(\theta_{90}\) are the temperatures at \(t = 0\) and \(t = 90 \text{s}\)
Include the unit for the cooling rate
Another student does this experiment with the same starting temperature but in a room with a much higher room temperature than \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) from (a)(i)
State how this affects his value of \(x\) in \(\mathbf{d}(\mathbf{i})\)
Explain your answer by reference to the results in Table 2.1 for the beaker with \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water
statement
explanation
Some thermal energy is lost from the sides of the beaker
The student wishes to find out how much this loss of thermal energy affects the cooling rate of \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of water
Briefly describe an additional experiment that the student can carry out to investigate this. Explain how the results can be used to determine how much this loss affects the cooling rate
additional experiment
use of results
A student investigates how the volume of water affects the rate at which water in a beaker cools
She uses the apparatus shown in Fig. 2.1
Fig. 2.1
On Fig. 3.1, measure the distance \(f_{1}\) between the illuminated triangle and the lens
Fig. 3.1 is drawn to \(1 / 5^{\text{th}}\) scale
Calculate the actual distance \(F_{1}\) between the illuminated triangle and the lens in this experiment. This is a value for the focal length of the lens
Briefly describe a technique to obtain an image on the card that is as sharp as possible in this experiment
The student sets the distance between the illuminated triangle and the mirror to \(40\mathrm{cm}\)
He moves the lens until he sees a sharp image of the triangle on the card, by the side of the illuminated triangle
Measure \(h_{\mathrm{O}}\), the height of the illuminated triangle as shown in Fig. 3.3
Measure \(h_{\mathrm{I}}\), the height of the image on the screen as shown in Fig. 3.4
Fig. 3.3 Fig. 3.4
Describe **one** difficulty when measuring the height of the image in this type of experiment. Suggest an improvement to overcome this difficulty
difficulty
improvement
Calculate a value \(W\) using the equation \(W = \frac{h_{\mathrm{O}}}{h_{\mathrm{I}}}\)
Calculate a second value \(F_{2}\) for the focal length of the lens, using the equation \(F_{2} = \frac{U}{(W + 1)}\)
The student sets the distance between the illuminated triangle and the lens to \(U = 20.0 \text{cm}\)
She moves the screen until a sharp image of the triangle appears on the screen
A student suggests that \(F_{1}\) and \(F_{2}\) should be equal
State whether the results support this suggestion
Justify your statement with reference to the results
statement
justification
Describe one precaution that can be taken to obtain reliable measurements of \(F_{1}\) and \(U\) in the experiment
Some students determine the focal length of a converging lens by different methods
One student uses the apparatus shown in Fig. 3.1
A student investigates the resistance of a light-dependent resistor (LDR)
The resistance of an LDR changes as the intensity of light falling on it varies
The resistance \(R\) of the LDR is calculated using the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)
where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the LDR and \(I\) is the current in the LDR
Plan an experiment to investigate how the light intensity affects the resistance of an LDR
The apparatus available includes:
an LDR
equipment to connect the circuit, part of which is shown in Fig. 4.1
a lamp with a power supply
In your plan, you should:
complete the circuit diagram in Fig. 4.1 to show a voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference across the LDR
state how the light intensity falling on the LDR will be varied and list any additional apparatus needed
explain briefly how to do the experiment, including any precautions taken to ensure reliable results
state one key variable to be kept constant
draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)
explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion
